newsitem.title: USA: Mexico coffee goal seen as optimistic - US attache.
newsitem.headline: Mexico coffee goal seen as optimistic - US attache.

text.p: A goal by Mexican coffee producers to boost production by 1 million bags annually for the next three years is "optimistic," an agricultural expert with the U.S. embassy in Mexico said Wednesday.
"That sounds pretty optimistic to me," said Norval Francis, the counselor for agricultural affairs at the embassy.

The Mexico Coffee Council said earlier this month it expected production to total 6 million 60-kg bags of coffee in the 1997-98 harvest, up from 5.1 million bags in the previous year. Growers are aiming to hike production by 1 million bags annually until the year 2000, then stabilize output at 8 million bags, the group said.
"The Mexican government is putting resources in to helping coffee producers," Francis said, speaking in an interview while visiting USDA headquarters.
"There's an incentive for the government to try and do something for areas of Mexico that are disadvantaged, with large numbers of indegenous people," he added.
The USDA last month forecast 1997/98 world coffee production at 103.7 million bags. The agency estimated Mexican exports at 4.8 million bags, up from 4.73 million bags in 1996/97.
